titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Michael De Lisio and Irving Drutman Papers
De Lisio (Michael) and Irving Drutman Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:15

did.unittitle: Michael De Lisio and Irving Drutman Papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers provide insight into the lives and careers of Michael De Lisio, poet and sculptor, and Irving Drutman, a journalist and editor. The papers contain drafts, research notes, and printed versions of De Lisio and Drutman's writings. Correspondence with various authors, artists, and performers, including Peter Bull, Janet Flanner, Lillian Gish, Ira Gershwin, and Lotte Lenya, also sheds light into their professional lives. De Lisio and Drutman's artwork, including De Lisio's sculptures of Ezra Pound and Marianne Moore, and several paintings by Drutman, are part of the papers. De Lisio's career as a sculptor can also be traced in his subject files, exhibition catalogues, and other printed material. Evidence of De Lisio and Drutman's relationship and personal lives can be found in their correspondence, personal papers, and photographs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 20 (videocassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 31 (Record Album Storage): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Michael De Lisio and Irving Drutman Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Michael De Lisio and Irving Drutman Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization.

The finding aid for this collection is compiled from a preliminary list that was created at or around the time of receipt by the library. The preliminary list was migrated to comply with current archival descriptive standards. As part of the migration, modifications were made to the formatting of the list; however, the content of the list was neither modified nor verified.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This collection includes materials previously identified by the following call number: Uncat Mss 500.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Irving Drutman (1910-1978)
bioghist.p: Irving Drutman (1910-1978), American journalist, editor, songwriter, and collector. Born Isidore Druitman to Max Druitman, an upholsterer, and Esther Druitman on July 28, 1910. Drutman wrote articles for the New York Herald Tribune and New York Times . In addition to theatrical journalism, Drutman's involvement in theatre and film also included working as a freelance publicist and songwriting, with songs including "Twilight Song," "Mama Never Told Me," and "Bel Ami." Drutman edited Janet Flanner's memoirs Paris Was Yesterday (1972) and London Was Yesterday (1975), and collected writings Janet Flanner's World (1979). Drutman published his memoir Good Company in 1976. He died of cancer on September 20, 1978 in New York City.

bioghist.head: Michael De Lisio (1911-2003)
bioghist.p: Michael De Lisio (1911-2003), American poet and sculptor. Born on January 22, 1911 in New York City. De Lisio published poetry in Scribner's and The New Yorker , the latter where he also worked in the office. He served with the navy during the second World War. De Lisio began creating artwork after a two-decade career in public relations for MGM. He exhibited at the Nova Scotia College of Art in Halifax (1969), Minneapolis Institute of Arts (1971), the Brooke Alexander Gallery (1978), the Princeton University Library, Smith College Museum of Art (1974 and 1980), and Boston College (1998). He died in New York City on January 21, 2003.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers provide insight into the lives and careers of Michael De Lisio, poet and sculptor, and Irving Drutman, a journalist and editor. The papers contain drafts, research notes, and printed versions of De Lisio and Drutman's writings. Correspondence with various authors, artists, and performers, including Peter Bull, Janet Flanner, Lillian Gish, Ira Gershwin, and Lotte Lenya, also sheds light into their professional lives. De Lisio and Drutman's artwork, including De Lisio's sculptures of Ezra Pound and Marianne Moore, and several paintings by Drutman, are part of the papers. De Lisio's career as a sculptor can also be traced in his subject files, exhibition catalogues, and other printed material. Evidence of De Lisio and Drutman's relationship and personal lives can be found in their correspondence, personal papers, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: I. Subject Files, 1932-2000. II. Correspondence, 1928-1999. III. Personal and Professional Papers, 1941-2002. IV. Writings, 1931-1992. V. Other Papers, 1924-1998. VI. Photographs, 1890-1990. VII. Printed Material, 1927-1995. VIII. Artwork, 1938-1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to topics of interest to De Lisio and Drutman. The Art Files contains information regarding De Lisio and Drutman's artwork and art collection as well as artists of interest. The last subseries contains files on individuals who De Lisio sculpted. The series also include correspondence relating to Drutman and De Lisio's artwork and collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: General, Art Files, and Subjects De Lisio Sculpted.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent and subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains De Lisio and Drutman's personal and professional correspondence reflecting their artistic circles. Correspondents include writers, artists, actors, and musicians, such as Peter Bull, Janet Flanner, Ira Gershwin, Lillian Gish, Lotte Lenya, Sonia Orwell, Hiram Sherman, and Raleigh Trevelyan. The series also includes correspondence between De Lisio and Drutman, dating from the 1930s to the 1960s, and which includes postcards illustrated by both De Lisio and Drutman.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into two subseries: Michael De Lisio and Irving Drutman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of drafts of writings, audiovisual material, correspondence, and royalty statements relating to De Lisio and Drutman's writings. Included are drafts of De Lisio's poetry and unpublished autobiography. Evidence of Irving Drutman's work as a lyricist, journalist, memoirist, and editor can be found in drafts, research notes, and correspondence reflecting his creative process. The series also provides insight into Drutman's work with Janet Flanner to publish her memoirs Paris Was Yesterday and London Was Yesterday and collected writings Janet Flanner's World . The series contains drafts for Drutman's memoir, Good Company and an unpublished sequel, Eccentric Characters, Dubious Company . Drutman's work as a lyricist can also be traced in the series, which contains his work with Jack Lawrence. De Lisio and Drutman's published writing can also be found in the Printed Materials series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes "Sunday Morning," "I'm Advertising for a Baby," "She Gave Up Love for Everything (Money, Money, Money)," "The Girl with the Mustache," "Do You or Don't You," "Come to the Circus," "Opening," "Mama Never Told Me," Suddenly It's Spring," "The World I Live In," "Don't Blame Me for Everything," "Tell Me No Stories," "Lullaby for Rain," "What Do You Care?," "My Future's a Thing of the Past," "Schmoos," "What the Hell," "The Cream in My Coffee," "Sunday Afternoon," "And So They Were Married," "The Naughty Naughty Nineties," "Be Red for the Red White and Blue," "The Twilight Song," and untitled. Includes lyrics written with Jack Lawrence.

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains legal and financial records, address books, scrapbooks, clippings, and other ephemera primarily relating to Irving Drutman. Drutman's career as a lyricist and publicist is documented in contracts, royalties, a list of films in which Drutman was involved, a phonodisc, and scrapbooks with clippings of various movies and plays. The series also provides insight into Drutman's work with performers such as Lotte Lenya and a notebook with anecdotes about his encounters with writers and artists, such as Janet Flanner and Virgil Thomson. The series also includes material relating to Drutman's death, including obituaries, a will, and a copy of his death certificate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes notebook "Notes made since 1935 in a cream-colored book, 'The Scribble-In Book' trade mark, which I bought at Woolworth's and on the spine of which I printed 'Anecdotes'."

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of photographs of Michael De Lisio, Irving Drutman, and their families dating from the 1890s to the 1990s. Photographs of De Lisio and Drutman range from formal portraits to snapshots of vacations abroad and at their property on Fire Island, Long Island. Photographs of De Lisio's artwork and exhibitions can be found in the series, including a proposed statue of Henry James for Washington Square Park in New York City. The series also contains signed portraits of celebrities.

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains printed material by and about De Lisio and Drutman. These include early poetry published by De Lisio in The New Yorker and later articles about his work as a sculptor, including a piece in Connoisseur and exhibition catalogues. Children's stories written by Drutman for the Works Progress Administration can also be found in this series.

did.unittitle: WPA stories for children by Irving Drutman (The Buried Treasure, The Proud Prince) and other authors (The Table and the Chair, Marco Polo, Princess Flinda, and The Crows and the Doves)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IX is organized into three subseries: Michael De Lisio, Irving Drutman, and Other Artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains artwork by De Lisio and Drutman, including two of De Lisio's sculptures and several paintings by Drutman. The series also includes portraits of De Lisio and Drutman by Al Hirschfeld and Larry Rivers.
